Authors:
Natalia Fraija-Fernandez, Francisco Javier Aznar, Antonio
Fernandez, Juan Antonio Raga, Mercedes Fernandez
Title:
Evolutionary relationships between digeneans of the family
Brachycladiidae Odhner, 1905 and their marine mammal hosts: a
cophylogenetic study
Keywords:
Digenea, Brachycladiidae, Cetacea, Pinnipedia, Sea Otter,
Cophylogeny
Abstract:
Digeneans of the family Brachycladiidae Odhner, 1905
occurs worldwide parasitizing hepatopancreatic ducts, intestine, lungs
and air sinuses of marine mammals. We study the evolutionary
relationships of this host-parasite system under a cophylogenetic
framework applying distance-based and event-based methods. A partial
phylogeny for the Brachycladiidae was constructed using mitochondrial
ND3 sequences of 9 parasite species, representing 6 out of the 10 genera
of the family. Host phylogeny was constructed using sequences of the
cytochrome b gene from 104 species of mammals. Distance-based methods
support the hypothesis of a global non-random association of host and
parasite phylogenies. Congruent links were observed in 24 out of the 50
individual host-parasite associations occurring in the Delphinoidea
clade, where brachycladiids are highly dispersed among species of
dolphins and porpoises. Colonization has been considered one of the main
drivers for the origin of parasitism in the marine realm, using the
digenean-marine mammal host-parasite system we quantify for the first
time the relative contribution of the evolutionary events implied in
their association. We found that loss and failure to diverge accounts
for the most frequently occurred events, followed by duplication, host
switching and cospeciation. We confirmed that colonization with or
without subsequent diversification has been decisive in the
establishment of the parasitic association between brachycladiids and
marine mammals. As brachycladiids are trophically-transmitted parasites
a common trophic guild is essential to this evolutionary processes to
occur.
